items.title: Supreme Court Backs a Controversial Railroad in Utah for Carrying Oil
items.description: The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled in favor of a controversial Utah railway project that critics say erodes the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), a bedrock of environmental law for the past half century. items.title: Clean Energy Project Cancellations Top $14 Billion So Far in 2025
items.description: Businesses have cancelled or delayed more than $14 billion of investments in U.S. clean energy projects so far this year, reflecting their uncertainty and pessimism over federal support amid President Donald Trump’s climate policy retreat, industry analysts reported Thursday. The sector still is showing resilience—at least $4.2 billion in new renewable energy, grid, electric vehicle […]

items.title: A Twinkle in Trump’s Eye: A Shakeup at Alabama’s Top Utility Regulator
items.description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.—Twinkle Cavanaugh, longtime president of the state’s top utility regulator, will begin working within days for the Trump administration as the state director for rural development in Alabama.  Cavanaugh will leave the Public Service Commission on June 1. Her move was announced by the federal Department of Agriculture among other appointees earlier this week.  […]

items.title: What Will Tariffs Do to the Energy Economy? Here Are Three Scenarios
items.description: The Trump administration’s ever-changing policies on tariffs and trade have injected chaos into the global energy economy. items.title: Pennsylvania Fracking Company Surrenders Water Permits Over Concerns About Stream Flow
items.description: A natural gas company has surrendered its permits to pump water from a western Pennsylvania creek in a move welcomed by environmentalists fearful of rising industrial demand for surface water and the growing threat of climate change. items.title: German Court Rejects Peruvian’s Claim of Climate Harms
items.description: After nearly 10 years of litigation, a regional civil court in Germany on Wednesday dismissed a Peruvian farmer’s claim that he and his community have been harmed by climate change driven by a German energy company’s emissions.  But at the same time, the court affirmed that such claims are permissible under German law. items.title: A Transco Pipeline Plan to Boost Gas in Five States Would Sharply Increase Air Pollution in N.C. Towns
items.description: Two compressor stations along Transco’s natural gas pipeline in North Carolina would emit more than 935,000 tons of planet-warming greenhouse gases each year, state records show. The expansion would also contaminate nearby communities with harmful air pollutants up to 350 percent over current levels. items.title: Maryland Advocates Call for Penalties on Washington Gas After Ruling on False Environmental Claims
items.description: Advocates are ramping up pressure on the Maryland Public Service Commission to penalize Washington Gas Light Company following a March ruling which found that the company misled millions of customers by claiming methane gas was better for the environment than electricity.  The ruling by Utility Law Judge Ryan McLean found that Washington Gas’s marketing statements […]

items.title: A Seabird Chick With 778 Pieces of Plastic in Its Body Shows How Bad Marine Pollution Has Gotten
items.description: For a seabird, it can be tough to tell the difference between a squid snack and a piece of plastic debris. items.description: With growing energy demand and delays in renewable energy rollout, New Jersey is doubling down on nuclear—its largest source of in-state electricity—and is now looking at positioning itself as a national leader in developing next-generation reactors.
